Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multivariate positive definite polynomials and their applications via SDP
Award.AbstractNarration: Musin<br/>DMS-0807640<br/>Barg<br/>DMS-0807411<br/><br/> This project is devoted to the study of point allocations on<br/>the real sphere and related configurations using methods of<br/>distance geometry, coding theory, and semidefinite programming. <br/>The properties of the point sets studied include restricting the<br/>minimum angular separation between any pair of distinct points in<br/>the set or the degree of the cubature formula supported by it. <br/>Recent advances in these problems include a solution by the<br/>investigator of the kissing number problem in 4 dimensions, a new<br/>proof for the kissing number problem in 3 dimensions, and a new<br/>approach to bounds on codes using semidefinite programming, due<br/>to Schrijver, Bachoc, and the investigator. The kissing problem<br/>in x dimensions is the question of how many unit spheres can<br/>touch (kiss) a unit sphere in x dimensions. The new ideas<br/>developed in these works pave the way for further advances in the<br/>problems of bounding the size of codes and in a number of other<br/>problems in distance geometry. <br/><br/> The main problems to be addressed in the project are related<br/>to bounding the size of optimal sets of points on a sphere when<br/>the sets have a certain property, and the links between the<br/>bounding problem and multivariate positive definite polynomials. <br/>Interesting properties of the point set include having a minimum<br/>angular separation that exceeds a given value between any two<br/>points in the set (this is relevant for signal processing<br/>problems), and supporting an exact cubature formula for spherical<br/>harmonic functions of a given degree. Applications of the point<br/>sets studied include communication theory, numerical analysis,<br/>the meshing problem, data representation, and localization in<br/>sensor networks.
